@mrhnm Yes, it's as much watching the video, so much as some material being more conducive to passive learning versus active.  Some materials are easy to understand, but hard to apply, because it requires you to learn certain skills to do things proficiently.  This type of task is hard to learn from just watching a video.

@Nomoreidsleft i have looked at something on the Khan Academy and aced tests without practice other I haven't.

@mynameismeowth I'm not try to tell you what higher education is, but simply describing it as I see it.  It takes active participation to learn, and not simply passively watching others do it.  Some students may think that because they understand something from a YouTube video that they will be able to breeze through exams.  But, it takes a lot of practice and hard work to learn some things, and be able to apply it in test situations. It's not hard to compile a kernel.  Check on YouTube.

@Nomoreidsleft Go to the khan academy website... The videos on youtube are not meant to be taken by themselves. They're﻿ used for explaining concepts and demonstrating problems only. Any student going through the academy still has to get many different problems in that area correct before being able to move on to the next concept.
Put 1000 Salman Khan's on this planet and everything would be fine within minutes.

You do a detailed explanation on the most important topics with concrete and precise examples that cover much more of the doubts of your viewers than traditional teaching which is based on traditional generations, and you keep them engaged enough to prevent boredom.
thanks so much, ur vids are so helpful
if we were all a little bit more like Khan, the world would be a better place.
We Love You KHAN!! Thank you for making me survive first year highschool..

@Nomoreidsleft Yes I have noticed that quite well, mainly when students study the night before exams or test. They may fully understand the formulas and concepts but apply them seem difficult to them as they have no or little previous practice with the topic. But when Khan is atm he is doing quite well. He basically clarifies things with detail so people fully understand that them, and then at school they can apply it to the work provided.

@G0DMASTERZ There's no doubt that Khan is smart, but what the kids watching his videos don't realize is that he did not get smart by passively watching video, and listening to lectures.  Not only do you need the basic concepts, it takes a lot of practice and repetition to actually pass exams.  In calculus, you can know perfectly well what a derivative and integral is, but if you don't practice applying the techniques for finding them, it will take you forever to finish an exam.
Sal, you are my inspiration!

@mynameismeowth Sorry, there's only so much good grammar possible in a UTube comment.

@MeansDarling Not a question of memorization versus understanding.  Ultimately both are needed in university.  Most profs worth their pay in university value understanding more than memorization.  However, the first couple of years are used to weed out the masses.  I think that we need more lessons that electronics based, so that students can review material at their own pace.  However, like I said, although Khan is smart, he's not smart enough to know all possible topics to the degree needed.
You should be Minister of Education of the World!
We love you for what you do

Khan's not really doing anything different that what you get in school.  The differences are that you can review his lectures repeatedly until you understand it, that he has a better grasp of most topics than some teachers.

Unfortunately, it will not translate to higher education beyond high school, because in university, you have to depend on your ability to grasp new subjects without depending on what your professor knows.  That's the nature of higher learning.
